title: 103_hr247
content:
The Act is titled the "Second National Blue Ribbon Commission to Eliminate Waste in Government Act" and establishes a commission with the duty to eliminate waste in government. The Commission is tasked with conducting surveys on management and cost control in the Federal Government, reviewing agency operations, and analyzing various reports for waste reduction recommendations. They are required to submit a report to the President and Congress with significant recommendations and estimated savings. The Commission is responsible for identifying opportunities for increased efficiency and reduced costs in the Federal Government through executive action or legislation. They also focus on enhancing managerial accountability, improving administrative control, terminating programs that have achieved their objectives, and evaluating program services that could be eliminated. The Commission aims to identify opportunities for cost reduction and efficiency in the Federal Government through executive action or legislation. This includes finding specific Federal program services that could be provided more cost-effectively by the private sector, proposing budget process reforms for savings and accountability, and pinpointing areas for further study to justify potential savings. SEC. 4. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 12 members appointed by the President based on their qualifications. Recommendations can be made by Senate and House leaders. No more than 6 members can be from the same political party. If a member joins the government, they can only remain on the Commission for 30 days. Appointments must be made within 30 days. Appointments to the Commission must be made within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Members serve for life and vacancies are filled within 30 days. Members serve without pay but receive travel expenses. A quorum consists of 5 members, and the Chairperson is elected from among the members. The Commission meets monthly, with the Chairperson calling the meetings. The Commission's Director is appointed by the Chairperson and paid by a rate set by the Commission. The Director can hire staff with Commission approval. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 6. The Commission, as outlined in Section 6, has the authority to hold hearings, receive evidence, delegate actions, obtain information from federal agencies, and enter into contracts for supplies or services. SEC. 7. REPORTS.

The Commission will issue periodic reports to the President and Congress as required by section 3(a)(3). A final report with findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislative and administrative actions must be submitted within 24 months of the Act's enactment.

SEC. 8. TERMINATION.

The Commission will terminate within 30 days of submitting the final report under section 7(b).

SEC. 9. FUNDING AND SUPPORT. The Commission will be funded, staffed, and equipped by the private sector without cost to the Federal Government, with support provided through a joint project with a nonprofit organization.
